1.q_string: The freezing point depression constant for water is \(-1.86^{\circ} \mathrm{Cm}^{-1}\). If \(5.00 \mathrm{~g}\) \(\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}\) is dissolved in \(45.0 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\), the freezing point is changed by \(3.82^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). Calculate the vant \(\mathrm{Hoff}\) factor for \(\mathrm{Na}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}\).
Benzene and naphthalene form an ideal solution at room temperature. For this process, the true statement(s) is(are):

A o.001 molal solution of \(\left[\mathrm{Pt}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{4} \mathrm{Cl}_{4}\right]\) in water has a freezing point depression of \(0.0054^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). If \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{f}}\) for water is \(1.80 \mathrm{~K} \cdot \mathrm{kg} \cdot \mathrm{mol}^{-1}\), the correct formulation of the above molecule is:
Which of the following represent(s) correctly the changes in thermodynamic properties during the formation of 1 mole of an ideal binary solution?

The vapour pressure of a certain liquid is given by the equation:

\(\log _{10} \mathrm{P}=3.54595+\frac{313.7}{\mathrm{~T}}+1.40655 \log _{10} \mathrm{~T}\), where, \(\mathrm{P}\) is the vapour pressure in \(\mathrm{mm}\) and \(\mathrm{T}\) is temperature in \(\mathrm{K}\). The molar latent heat of vaporisation as a function of temperature and its value in cal at \(80 \mathrm{~K}\) is :

Let the solubilities of \(\mathrm{AgCl}\) in \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}, 0.01 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{CaCl}, 0.01 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{NaCl}\) and \(0.05 \mathrm{M}\)

\(\mathrm{AgNO}_{3}\) be \(\mathrm{s}_{1}, \mathrm{~s}_{2}, \mathrm{~s}_{3}\) and \(\mathrm{s}_{4}\) respectively. What is the correct relationship between these quantities?

q_option: Both Assertion and Reason are correct and Reason is the correct explanation for Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are correct but Reason is not the correct explanation for Assertion
Assertion is incorrect but Reason is correct
1.q_string:
Assertion: All solutes become more soluble in water at higher temperature.

Reason: Solubility of solute depends upon temperature.

The vapour pressures of two liquids A and B in their pure states are in the ratio of 1 : 2. A binary solution of A and B contains A and B in the mole proportion of 1 : 2. The mole fraction of A in the vapour phase of the solution will be:

Van't Hoff factor of centimolal solution of \(\mathrm{K}_{3}\left[\mathrm{Fe}(\mathrm{CN})_{6}\right]\) is \(3 \cdot 333\). Calculate the percent dissociation of \(\mathrm{K}_{3}\left[\mathrm{Fe}(\mathrm{CN})_{6}\right]\).
At same temperature which pair of the following solutions are isotonic?

Which one of the following electrolytes has the same value of van't Hoff's factor

(i) as that of \(\mathrm{Al}_{2}\left(\mathrm{SO}_{4}\right)_{3}\) (if all are \(100 \%\) ionised)?
For an ideal liquid solution, which of the following is unity?
The volume vs. temperature graph of 1 mole of an ideal gas is given below. The pressure of the gas (in atm) at \(\mathrm{X}, \mathrm{Y}\) and \(\mathrm{Z}\), respectively, are:

Two liquids \(\mathrm{X}\) and \(\mathrm{Y}\) form an ideal solution at \(300 \mathrm{~K}\), the vapour pressure of the solution containing 1 mole of \(X\) and 3 moles of \(Y\) is \(550 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{Hg}\). At the same temperature, if 1 mole of \(\mathrm{Y}\) is further added to this solution, the vapour pressure of the solution increases by \(10 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{Hg}\). Vapour pressure (in \(\mathrm{mm} \mathrm{Hg}\) ) of \(\mathrm{X}\) and \(\mathrm{Y}\) in their pure states will be respectively:

q_option: Plot of \(1 / \rho_{\text {total }}\) vS \(1 / \mathrm{Y}_{\mathrm{A}}\), mole fraction of \(\mathrm{A}\) in vapour phase
1.q_string: Which of the following shows behavior of binary liquid solution?

The following is a graph plotted between the vapour pressure of two volatile liquids against their respective mole fractions. 

Which of the following statements is/are correct ?

Which one of the following is the ratio of the lowering of vapour pressure of \(0.1 \mathrm{M}\) aqueous solutions of \(\mathrm{BaCl}_{2}, \mathrm{NaCl}\) and \(\mathrm{Al}_{2}\left(\mathrm{SO}_{4}\right)_{3}\) respectively?
The lowering in vapour pressure is maximum for:

When a liquid that is immiscible with water was steam distilled at \(95.2^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) at a total pressure of \(99.652 \mathrm{kPa}\), the distillate contained \(1.27 \mathrm{~g}\) of the liquid per gram of water. What will be the molar mass of the liquid if the vapour pressure of water is \(85.140 \mathrm{kPa}\) at \(95.2^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) ?

Two closed vessels of an equal volume containing air at pressure \(P_{1}\) and temperature \(T_{1}\) are connected to each other through a narrow tube. If the temperature in one of the vessels is now maintained at \(T_{1}\) and that in the other at \(\mathrm{T}_{2}\), what will be the pressure in the vessels?

Equal mass of \(\mathrm{H}_{2}, \mathrm{He}\) and \(\mathrm{CH}_{4}\) are mixed in empty container at \(300 \mathrm{~K}\), when total pressure is \(2.6 \mathrm{~atm}\). The partial pressure of \(\mathrm{H}_{2}\) in the mixture is:

q_option: \(\mathrm{CaCl}_{2}\) (s) acts as drying agent under given condition.
\(\mathrm{CaCl}_{2}(\mathrm{~s})\) acts as hygroscopic substance given condition.
Mass of \(\mathrm{CaCl}_{2} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{s})\) increases due to some reaction.
1.q_string:
\(\mathrm{CaCl}_{2} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{s}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{CaCl}_{2}(\mathrm{~s})+6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{g}) ; \mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{p}}=6.4 \times 10^{-17}\). Excess solid

\(\mathrm{CaCl}_{2} \cdot 6 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\) and \(\mathrm{CaCl}_{2}\) are taken in a container containing some water vapours at a pressure of \(1.14\) torr at a particular temperature. Which of the following is true?

Two volatile liquids \(\mathrm{A}\) and \(\mathrm{B}\) an mixed in mole ratio \(1: 3\), to form an ideal liquid solution. Vapour pressure of pure \(A\) and B are 600 torr and 200 torr. Volume of container for vapour is 76 litre. \((R=\frac1 { 12}\) litre \(\mathrm{atm} / \mathrm{K} / \mathrm{mole}\).Calculate the mole of \(\wedge\) in vapour phase at \(300 \mathrm{~K}\), assuming negligible amount of vapour is present compared to liquid in container.

The vapour pressure of the solution containing \(30 \mathrm{g}\). of non-volatile solute of molecular weight \(60 \mathrm{in} 360 \mathrm{gm}\) of water approximately at \(30^{\circ} \mathrm{c}\) is: ( vapour pressure of water at \(30^{\circ} \mathrm{c}=24 \mathrm{~mm}\) of \(\mathrm{Hg}\) )

The vapour pressure of pure benzene at a certain temperature is \(640 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{Hg}\). A non-volatile solute weighing \(2.175 \mathrm{~g}\) is added to \(39.0 \mathrm{~g}\) of benzene. The vapour pressure of solution is \(600 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{Hg}\). What is the molar mass of the solute?
